comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Between 1880 (Colonial Secretary's Office completed) and 1895 (dome added).

These were the houses whose view was ruined by the Garden Palace (1879-82).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
They are a fine set of balconies .  Reverse view by Henry King - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2532451039/]

comment.author: 70994841@N07
comment._content: What a wonderful row of terraces....each one different and charming in it's own way.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This is the image I was thinking of - how would you like this built in your front yard? - 1879 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=846071&am... (from the excellent Mullins album, SLNSW - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=836375 )

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: One of these houses is still there, but I can't work out which it is - HELP! - GoogleMapsStreetView - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Macquarie+St,+Sydney+NSW&hl...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yep, I agree with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs]'s note. In fact, today it's "History House", 133 Macquarie Street, where the Royal Australian Historical Society is based. - www.rahs.org.au/our-heritage-building . NSW Heritage Register entry - www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDe...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thank you,  I had a feeling it was that one (3 levels of balcony and 3 dormer windows) but could not reconcile the first floor metal balustrade. 

Interested that " From 1892 until 1922 the house was used as a boarding house, as were many other such buildings in Macquarie Street. "  (from the 2nd link above),  which explains why the other houses are not looking 100% smart.  Maybe the Public Works Department had its eye on the houses for some grandiose building,  hence this photo?

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: yes it was open for "Sydney Open" last weekend sydneyopen.hht.net.au/building/history-house/#city-pass Poor owner George Oakes was hit by a tram and did not enjoy it for long :(

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: John Rae also seems to have owned one or more of these buildings, which might explain this photo. I can't seem to match up the top floors. See - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=169398 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=169397 And he took a p@n*r@m@ from the top - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=168162 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=168039 (wildcard?) acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=168161 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=168160# acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=168159 I wonder if this has something to do with anything?
